header.title: Healing Plants and Animals from a Distance: Curative Principles and Applications
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Shamanism, Energy Healing, Native American Spirituality

central_thesis: The book proposes that holistic healing for all beings, including humans, plants, and animals, is achieved by consciously re-establishing a 'right relationship' with the natural world. This involves shifting from a left-brained, separatist perception to a right-brained, interconnected, shamanic understanding of reality. Through focused intent, energy work, and dialogue with nature spirits and divine powers, individuals can act as co-creators to restore balance and harmony, transcending physical distance through the holographic and non-linear nature of the universe.

structure_content.chapter_title: Preface: The Plant and Animal Nations
structure_content.summary: Introduces the concept of 'plant and animal nations' from a Native American perspective, emphasizing mutual respect and interdependence as 'Children of Earth and Sky.' Contrasts this with the Western 'man vs. nature' view. Highlights the importance of biophilia—the innate human need for connection to life—as foundational for healing, which is defined as restoring wholeness and harmony. Offers historical examples of indigenous sustainable practices.

Explores the core principle of healing as achieving 'hozho' (balance, ease, harmony) and the interconnectedness of all beings, stating 'We Are All One, We Are The World.' Draws parallels between ancient wisdom (Medicine Wheel) and modern physics (holographic universe, quantum entanglement). Introduces the 'heyoka' (contrary) way of seeing and the importance of right-brain, intuitive thinking over left-brained rationality in spiritual matters. Includes exercises like the 'Ceremony of The Medicine Wheel of the Four Directions' to connect with cosmic powers.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Two: Animals and Plants as Helpers
structure_content.summary: Details how to communicate with plant and animal nations by 'remembering' inherent abilities and reaching the 'Stillpoint.' Presents Native American stories illustrating human-nature relationships. Explains the individual's 'personal energy field' (54-foot radius) and the 'Butterfly Effect' as a mechanism for distance healing through focused intent. Describes four energy healing modalities: channeling, reflecting, taking on, and melding. Introduces sacred healing symbols (Tesseract, Umane, Antahkarana) and Reiki as tools.

Outlines the practice of shamanic journeying as a method for 'seeing' in non-ordinary reality (Dreamtime). Explains the three 'worlds' (Upper, Middle, Lower) and how drumming (Earth Mother's heartbeat, ~70 bpm) facilitates entry. Focuses on meeting and working with one's 'power animal' in the Lower World and interpreting symbolic visions for guidance and healing. Emphasizes the role of intent and discernment in journeying.

Provides practical applications of the healing principles. Covers personal energy balancing ('Being the Eagle' exercise), creating sacred circles for ceremonies, and enlisting 'Powers' (divine beings, guides, ancestors, power animals) through gratitude. Offers techniques for hands-on healing with Earth energy, distance healing with crystals and symbolic representations (kachinas), soul retrieval for plants and animals using rattling, and learning the 'song' or signature frequency of beings for healing and immunity. Reaffirms the 'Law of Attraction' within a framework of peace and respect.

key_concepts.definition: In shamanic terms, healing is the restoration of balance, ease, harmony, and wholeness to a being or situation, rather than merely curing symptoms. It involves aligning with the natural state of the world.

A multidimensional circle representing the universe and the interconnectedness of all things, serving as a framework for understanding and enacting healing and balance in the world. It encompasses all beings and energies within its scope.

From Lakota, meaning 'backwards way' or contrary wisdom. It refers to a way of perceiving reality where paradoxes (e.g., light is dark, forward is backward) reveal deeper truths. It's associated with divine wisdom, sacred clowns (koshares), and seeing things from an inverted or unconventional perspective to understand unity.

An inner place of total silence and stillness within oneself, where internal dialogue ceases. It is identified as the source of intuition, creativity, and the point from which one can truly 'listen' and connect with other beings and the divine.

The energetic aura surrounding the physical body, extending approximately 27 feet in all directions in the physical plane (and further into other dimensions). It is a field through which individuals constantly interact with their surroundings and can consciously extend their awareness and influence.

A method of energy healing where the practitioner allows a divine being or higher power to use their body as a 'hollow bone' or conduit to transmit healing energy to another being (person, plant, or animal). Reiki is cited as an example.

An energy healing technique where the practitioner uses their own energy field as a mirror to show the treated being (person, plant, or animal) what is missing or out of balance. By being a 'perfect mirror' of wholeness, the practitioner enables the other being to 'see' its own inherent perfect state and initiate self-healing.

A potentially dangerous method of energy healing where the practitioner intentionally absorbs the dis-ease or illness of the treated being into their own body for transmutation. This technique requires intense spiritual training, purification, and grounding (e.g., Bear Dance).

Becoming energetically 'one' with the person, plant, or animal being treated. This involves a temporary overlapping of consciousness and energy fields, allowing for shared understanding and the removal of dis-ease while retaining individual essential selves. It's particularly recommended for plants and animals.

A concept from chaos theory, applied spiritually, suggesting that infinitesimal changes in initial conditions (such as focused intent) can have vast, unpredictable, and ultimately beneficial outcomes. It underscores the profound interconnectedness of all things and the potential for miracles through conscious engagement.

A sacred geometry symbol, also known as a hypercube, 8-cell, or octachoron. Used as a healing symbol to excite inherent higher wisdom and facilitate 'angel healing' by creating doorways for positive energies due to its geometric properties representing connections between dimensions.

A Lakota term and sacred symbol meaning 'Earth power.' It is often depicted as a square with lines emanating outwards, representing Earth's raw energy fueling ceremonies and encircling the globe, connecting with the universe's powers.

An ancient healing and meditation symbol used in Tibet and China for thousands of years. It can effect healing and positive change simply by its presence, enhancing chakras and aura, and is used to invite good energies.

A practice involving entering a non-ordinary state of consciousness (often induced by drumming) to travel to 'non-ordinary reality' (e.g., Upper, Middle, Lower Worlds) to gain insights, seek guidance, or perform healing work, accessing information beyond normal sensory perception.

A spirit helper, typically an animal, that acts as a guide, protector, and source of power for an individual. It resides in the 'lower world' during shamanic journeys and provides guidance, support, and protection in all realms.

A shamanic ceremony to retrieve lost energetic 'pieces' or 'essence' of a soul that have been ejected due to trauma (e.g., accidents, divorce, abuse). It aims to restore life force, wholeness, and balance. The practice can be applied to plants and animals as well, typically using rattling.

key_concepts.term: Song of the Plant or Animal
key_concepts.definition: The unique signature frequency or vibrational rate of a specific plant or animal species, with minute individual differences. Learning and 'singing' this song back to the being can facilitate healing, reinforce its spirit form, and potentially confer immunity from harm by that species.

A non-linear perception of time accessed in non-ordinary reality, where past, present, and future are experienced as existing simultaneously in the 'now.' Those 'touched by the Thunderbird' are said to operate within this state, connecting disparate events in time.

The measurable energetic level of a person, place, or object. Higher vibrational rates are associated with closer alignment to Creator, divine consciousness, and states of harmony, enabling synchronicity and healing. Emotions and thoughts directly influence one's vibrational rate.

In Toltec shamanism, the term for 'non-ordinary reality' or 'what is really real,' which encompasses everything that can be, contrasted with the 'tonal' (consensus reality or what we think is real). It is the realm accessed through shamanic practices.

practical_system.description: The operative system presented is a form of 'environmental shamanism' that facilitates distant healing of plants and animals (and humans) by consciously shifting one's perception to 'non-ordinary reality' (All Time/No Time). It leverages the holographic nature of the universe and the interconnectedness of all beings. The practitioner aims to become a 'hollow bone' or 'reflector' of divine energy, using focused intent, ceremonies, and specific techniques to raise vibrational rates and bring about balance and wholeness.
tools: Drum (preferably a hand drum for ~70 bpm beat)
Rattle (for energy work and soul retrieval)
Cornmeal, corn pollen, tobacco (as offerings in ceremonies)
Small white ball (ping pong or golf ball) and marker pens (for 'God's Marble' exercise)
Notebook or journal (for recording dreams, journeys, and observations)
Crystals (quartz, various healing stones, for distant healing setups)
Tripod (for suspending crystals in healing setups)
Dolls, crafted figures, or photographs (as symbolic representations of beings for distant healing, 'kachinas')
Herbal dietary supplements (Melatonin, Potassium Gluconate, Gingko, St. John’s Wort – recommended with prior doctor consultation for journeying assistance)
rituals: Ceremony of The Medicine Wheel of the Four Directions: Connect with Creator and elemental powers (unoli) through offerings (cornmeal, pollen, tobacco) at sunrise, aligning with new beginnings, vigor, introspection, and wisdom.
Creating God’s Marble (Heyoka Exercise): Meditating on a painted sphere representing the three-dimensional Medicine Wheel to internalize oneness and non-linear perception ('heyoka').
Finding the Stillpoint: Cultivating inner silence through Gassho Meditation (clasping hands, focusing on fingers, brushing aside thoughts) to access intuition and hear non-verbal communication.
Taking Inventory (Thoughts & Emotions): Consciously noting and releasing limiting thoughts and emotions to align with one's authentic self and practice discernment of energy attachments.

Grounding, Centering, and Shielding: Visualizing an energy thread to the Earth, drawing Earth/Sun energy to the midsection for balanced awareness, and creating a protective energetic cocoon (e.g., white/blue light, mirrors) through intent.

Connecting With Plants and Animals ('Crazy Eights'): Melding one's energy field with plants/animals through resonance and overlapping consciousness in the 'here and now' to achieve common understanding and shared knowledge.

Creating a Sacred Circle: Establishing a consecrated space in nature by walking clockwise, sprinkling offerings (tobacco, cornmeal), and smudging (sage, cedar) to invite sacred energies and set intent for healing.

Hands-On Healing with Earth Energy ('Being the Eagle'): Balancing personal energies through specific postures (e.g., drawing arms to chest, extending like eagle wings) and breathwork, channeling Earth and Creator energy.

Distance Healing with Crystals and Symbols: Placing a representative object (doll, photo) of the plant/animal within a sacred circle drawn with symbols (Tesseract, Umane, Antahkarana) and programming crystals with heart energy, placed at cardinal points, for time-release healing.

Soul Retrieval of Plants and Animals: Using a rattle in a sacred circle with intent to call back lost soul pieces, allowing them to reestablish themselves in the treated being. Giving conscious intent of 'allowing' aids the process.

Learning the Song of the Plant or Animal: Through drumming, shamanic journey, or meditation, perceive the unique signature frequency ('song') of a plant or animal. Singing it back reinforces its spirit form for healing and can confer immunity from its potential harms.

Enlisting the Powers: Invoking divine beings (Creator, Earthly Mother, Heavenly Father, Guides, Angels, Power Animals, Ancestors, Goddesses, Divine Beings of Light) with affirmations of gratitude for their presence and healing assistance in ceremonies.

relevant_quotes.text: The Indian prefers the soft sound of the wind darting over the face of the pond, the smell of the wind itself cleansed by a midday rain. … The air is precious to the red man, for all things are the same breath — the animals, the trees, the man.

The first peace, which is the most important, is that which comes within the souls of people when they realize their relationship, their oneness with the universe and all its powers, and when they realize that at the center of the universe dwells the Great Spirit, and that this center is really everywhere, it is within each of us.
It’s a poor sort of memory that only works backwards.
The tree which moves some to tears of joy is inthe eyes of others only a green thing which stands in the way. … As the eye is formed, such are its powers.
The survival of the world depends on our sharing what we have, and working together. If we do not, the whole world will die. First the planet, and next the people.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book is highly relevant in contemporary esotericism as it synthesizes shamanic practices, Native American spirituality, and concepts from modern science (e.g., quantum entanglement, sacred geometry, biophilia) into a coherent system for practical application. It addresses the growing need for ecological and holistic healing, positing that human well-being is intrinsically linked to the health of the plant and animal kingdoms. The emphasis on 'right relationship' offers a potent counter-narrative to exploitative anthropocentric views, providing actionable methods for environmental stewardship rooted in spiritual practice. It expands traditional occult perspectives by offering specific techniques for energetic interaction with non-human entities at a distance.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes practitioners of shamanism, energy healing (like Reiki), environmental activists seeking spiritual grounding, and individuals interested in Native American spiritual traditions. It is also for occultists exploring the operative aspects of universal interconnectedness, sympathetic magic, and non-linear causality. The book appeals to those who are willing to move beyond purely intellectual frameworks and engage in experiential, right-brained practices, and who seek to integrate personal spiritual development with planetary healing.
